div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for [PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from SUAKIN every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves SUEZ for JEDDAH continuing every other week for SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond JEDDAH but call at TOR (for SINAI) EL WEDJ and YAMBO as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.

div.head: Avis Important
div.p: Mess. Rizzo & Co., éditeurs propriétairer de l'Egyptian Directory (l'Annusine Egyptien), tiennent à mettre le Public en garde contre les agissements de certaines personnes qui sollicitent et se fout remettre d'avance de l'argent pour insertions et annonces dans des publications qualifiées de différents titres et qui n'out jamais vu le jour.

Afin d'éviter tontes confluions et surprises Mess. Rizzo & Co informent le Public d'Alexandrie que tontes insertions et annonces dans l'Egyptian Directory doivent être remiser à leurs Agents, Mess. Kern. Gallois & Co, et sont payables après apparition du volume.

Grâce à la collaboration de leurs nombreux Agents, Mess. Rizzo & Co ont apporté d'importantes modifications et rectifications à leur édition 1907, qui paraîtra en Janvier prochain, et ils se flattent de présenter au Public un ouvrage toujours plus complet, plus correct et plus intéressant.

Les personnel qui auraient des changements d'adresse à notifier, sent priéss de les transmettre sans retard directectment au Caire aux bureaux de l'Administration Centrale "The Egyptian Directory" Sharia Kassr-el-Nil. 28,566-3-2

div.head: GERMANY AND ENGLAND.
div.p: An English resident in Germany contributes the following to the "Pall Mall Gazette":-

The eyes of all German Imperialists are fixed with a peculiar intensity of interest upon Great Britain just now. Needless to say, the apparently set purpose of this country to diminish its defensive and offensive land and the power is accepted—with hardly concealed satisfaction— as a further indication of that decline in national vigour which German political students have for some time included in their calculations for the future.

I cannot better suggest the picture which we present to this penetrating people at the moment than by quoting the recent observation of a German friend —a man whose word are sometimes echoed in this country—during some references to the future influence of arbitration and the limitation of armaments, in whose interest certain weak-kneed Britons have been acclaiming the retrenchment policy of the present Government.

"England most please herself, although we cannot view without some apprehension a growing weakness which, with the certainty of a natural law, most ultimately produce displacement of power and consequently international disturbance. You have your Navy? Certainly; but see, my friend, in precisely the same way does a not possess its shell, but if the kernel of the nut is withered and shrunken, the resisting power of the unsupported shell is very materially reduced. So with a nation. Nothing seems clearer to a close student of your race than that your Navy is covering a withering and shrinking virility and vigour both of body and mind. And I ask you to consider of the result if two nuts—one whose kernel is sound,the other decayed—are crushed together in the strong grip of war.

"As for us, your leagues of peace and international arbitrations are as the crackling of thorns beneath a pot. They can never abolish war, for in the society of nattions interests are so interwoven that the arbitrator States can never be impartial. Therefore, we Germans hold with your Lord Bacon, that wars are "the highest trials of right" National existence is dependent on power, and Bismarck spoke for Germany to all time when he said. The only healthy basis for a great State is national selfishness, and not romantic idealism. Not by speeches and resolutions of majorities are great questions decided, but by blood and iron." So Germany, my friend, is determined to rely for her greatness or, blool and iron, and noton beautiful sentiments and foreign investments. The shell of the German nut shall be strong and hard, but behind that the sound kernel of a resolute and vigorous race."
Again, another very pregnant remark was made to me by a German merchant prince who has identified himself very closely with the Colonial movement.

"Do not you Englishmen," he said, '"ever stop to consider what egotists you are when you talk about leagues for the preservation of international peace, now that you have got all the territory you can possibly want? But you must be very simple egotists as well if you believe that such beautiful sentiments will cause Germany to rest satisfied with the fact that, while England has practically all the colonies in the world, Germany has none"

We shall better appreciate the significance of such utterances if we realise that the foundation of Germany's political belief is that "Macht geht vor Recht"-' Might is Safer than Right " and so long as one powerful nation in the community of nations and rises to this faith it would be the height of folly for any other race or people to omit it from their defensive calculations.

Moreover, such a creed has too much historical foundation for us to ignore it. As another German, with the characteristic scholarship of his race, put it to me: "Neither right nor chance, not the instinct and the will of expansion, supported by might, have created British

tions. By tbhe right of the stronger, only, England herself has become possessed of her enormous Empire. By the right of the stronger the Hohenzollerns, a poor Swabian family who came to the wilds of Prussia with a handful of retainers a few centuries ago have created modern Germany. To might all States owe the title of their possessions, and by might only can their possessions be retained."

And here, touching the question of the maintenance of armaments, let me mention an argument which I have heard in the months of responsible Germans of high standing among their fellows, for it is an argument which ruthlessly exposes the ostrich-like fallacy of estimating national economic progress without any comparative reference to that of commercial competitors and possible foes. Now Germans, when dealing with the question of armaments, are fond of quoting Bismarck's dictum to the effect that "it is true that great armies are a great burden ; but by our armsments we are able to conduct a kind of warfare with the other nations, in which we give blanks with our money-bags" On this text they argue that as their wealth increases they are enabled to employ a portion of it in the increase of armaments to very great advantage, not only in national protection, but in wearing down the resources of their competitors. The game of empire, they very justly argue, is a costly one; it is like bidding at an auction, and the richest win?. "Either," say they, "by the continuance of expenditure on armaments, we compel our rivals to pursue the same course or to retire from the contest." That Great Britain is beginning to flinch from the burden of the contest, and not that she is in any degree inspired by a genuine humanitarianism at the present moment—that, in fact, she is, in a comparative sense, on the down grade both economically and physically—is the firm conviction of every keenly interested Teuton.

Speaking as one who is familiar with the economic conditions of both countries equally well, I am not inclined to contest the validity of their argument. If these relative conditions continue as they exist at the present moment, it is a moral certainty that in process of time Germany, who was never cursed by an evil genuine in the shape of a Teuton Cobden, must become top dog. For in Great Britain, as a result of Mr. Cobden's brilliant ideas, Free Trade has depopulated the country districts, mined our agriculture, and driven 10,000,000 British workers, with several millions of our national capital, out of Great Britain into Protectionist countries.

Through "the blessing of Free Trade" our industries have become partly stationary, partly retrogressive, partly decadent;and our population, whicb in the days of our prosperity used to increase faster than that of any other country, is gradually becoming stationary, whilst that of Germany, in spite of her inferior industrial resources, in spite of conscription, is rapidly growing under the "blighting influence of Protection." For "the supply of men is determined by the demand for men." And thus, while Great Britain, with a world wide Empire to supply with men and women, can only add every year 400,000 to her population, mostly paupers and unemployed, Germany adds some thing like a million prosperous workers to hers. While the general prosperity of the German race, under Protection, is stimulating national self-confidence, vigour, and push, our once manly British race, babbling of Free Trade hibboleths, is degenerating into a puny, sickly, ill-nonrished, sterile, incapable. and unhappy alum proletarist.

Bringing, therefore, his penetrating intellect to bear upon this picture of comparative national evolution, the German has deduced therefrom a conclusion, scientifically irrefutable, that in these rival conditions lies the most desirable solution of his greatest problem. For he argues thus: "As soon as the moral and material decay at present visible in the British race enables us to wrest from it the command of the sea, we shall have no difficulty in creating the Great Germany we require." And as showing the; deep saturation of these ideas there are not wanting sage and thinking Germans who go so far in their speculation as to say: -

"Under Germany, the British Colonies, and even Great Britain herself, with her matchless resources, properly developed, could in a few years be made marvellously prosperous by a sensible administration, the enforcement of discipline on the German model, by the development of her natural resources, and, above all, by the protection of her industries. A German administration of Great Britain would care nothing for the cheap applause of the electorate, but would adopt a policy which, however unpopular at first, would give to the workers solid advantages instead of imaginary and superficial ones."

The record of undoubted facts is quite sufficient to show the course of policy with regard to this country upon which Germany his entered, and no professions or manifestations of sympathy and regard on the part of Germany or ourselves can alter or explain away these facts. Germany is not only preparing with feverish haste for a naval struggle with Great Britain, but meantime is endeavouring to weaken this country by fostering ill feeling between ourselves and others, and by undermining our economic strength.

The tension, therefore, between the two nations is bound to increase to the breaking, point unless Germany shows by deeds, not words that she means to steer her political ship in another direction. At present she dominates the Continent, but if her frontiers become farther extended, her military, naval, and industrial power might become irresistible.

Let me quote my first friend once more. "I am unable," he observed, somewhat pungently, to understand British ill-will towards Germany. You deliberately choose physical and economic decadence in the interests of Free Trade and German commerce, and you complain if we increase more greatly in wealth and power than you do. It would be just as logical, my friend, to quarrel with the operation of a British ship.

div.head: Caisse de la Dette
div.p: The directors of the Caisse de la Dette will return to Cairo on Sunday.
Egyptian Quail
In England Large quantities of quail from Egypt for the London markets are being landed at Dover on the French mail steamers.
Khedivial Law School
Sheikh Ahmed Ibrahim, of the Cairo Ulema, been appointed professor of Mohamedan law at the Khedivial Law School.
Day of Atonement
All the local banks will be closed on Saturday, the 29th inst., as the Jewish Day of Atonement is celebrated on that date.
Ruled
Abou El-Maatl The Ministry of the Interior has given mission for the mouled of Sayid Abou El- Maatl to be held at Damietta between the 18th inst. and the 3rd prox.
Restaurant and Hotel, Khartoum.
The popular Grand Hotel of Khartoum is to be rebuilt, and the new plans show many improvements upon the present building, which will be considerably enlarged.
Theft from the Governor.

The Attarin Native Court of Appeal yesterday sentenced the three servants who had stolen rellery from the residence of H.E. the Governor of Alexandria, a few weeks ago, to the year's imprisonment with hard labour.
Tantah Munlolpallty.

The Tantah Municipal Council has decided to expend the sum of L.E. 200 on the reception which will be held for the Khedive on his Highness' arrival at Tantah, where he will be beside at the ceremony of opening the Agricultural Show.
Egyptian State Railways

Owing to the new half hourly local service between the Suez docks and Rue Colmar being extended to the Arbacen new station at the connection, slight alterations have been necessitated in the main line service, as well as the Suez docks trains.
Sidi-Gaber Moulod

The mouled of Sidi Gerber will be held to tomorrow evening at Sidi Gaber, Ramleh, where large number of native of Alexandria and all the neighbouring villages will attend the ceremony. The mouled will be contained until the 5th of October.
Nile Valley Co.

Mr. Noel Griffin, who has been appointed manager of the Nile Valley Company, has arrived in Egypt. The shareholders are to be congratulated upon having secured his services, and the devolopmeut of the property should upon show marked progress under his able management.
Increase of Cairo Police Force

It is stated that an increase is contemplated in the number of kisms of Cairo, urban and suburban, in view of the increasing population which is now disproportional to the standing force of 2,000 police. The Ministry of the Interior applied for a new credit to carry out this increase.
Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd.

Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi will open a new branch at San Stefano on Saturday afternoon for the benefit of their Ramleh clients. The service at this branch will be in no way inferior to that of the well known main stores and it is trusted that their customers will continue to support them by taking advantage of the new stores.
Walker and Malmarachi, Ltd

A Cairo contemporary remarks that it has good reason to believe that the reported differences which occurred between Mr. Meimarachi and the board of directors were smoothed over at the meeting which was held in London on Tuesday. It will be remembered that though confident assertions of difficulties were made no confirmation of the reports were obtainable either here or at Cairo.
Cordon Memorial Church.

An article pointing out the bad impression left on the Musulman mind in the Sudan by the non completion of the Gordon Memorial Church at Khartoum recently appeared in the "Record." The Duchess of Grafton has since intimated to the editor a subscription from her relative the Comtess de Nosilles. The Sirdar has expressed much pleasure at the Comtesse's action, and has suggested that subscriptions be remitted to Major Phipps, or secretary, Khartoum Church Fund, Khartoum.
Alhambra Theatre.

The Geisha will again be given at the Alhambra Theatre, Alexandria, this evening, on which occasion Signora Giuseppina Calligaris, who takes the role of the French "Mamzelle" will take her benefit. The play will be followed by a parody on the fourth act of El Traiature. On Friday the theatre will be closed for the Jewish holiday and on Saturday the Turkish troupe will make their debut in Les Sangtantes Naces d'Anatolie to be followed by songs by Miles Rise Aly, Paraseva and A Belnian.
New Employment Registry

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register which may be consulted by members resulting clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE COLDSTREAM GUARDS.
div.p: INSPECTED PRIOR TO DEPARTURE.
( Gazotto's Special Service. )
London, Wednesday.

The third Battalion Coldstream Guards were inspected yesterday previous to their departure for Egypt on Saturday. No troops could have presented a finer sight than this famous battalion which has been doomed to disbandment, and there were many hopes expressed that the indefinite postponement necessitated by their going to Egypt, where it is unknown how long they will remain, will save them.

div.head: THE BRUNSWICK DUCHY.
div.p: DUKE OF CUMBERLAND'S POSITION.
Berlin, September 26.
The Diet of Brunswick has passed a resolution inviting the Duke of Cumberland to sink his claim to the kingdom of Hanover and assume the rulership of the Duchy. [Reuter.]

The Duke of Cumberland is the son of the second Duke,who was King George V. of Hanover, fourth brother of the Duke of Kent, the father of the late Queen Victoria. He is married to a sister of Queen Alexandra.

The last Duke of Brunswick was Wilhelm I., born April 25, 1806, the second son of Duke Friedrich Wilhelm and of Princess Marie of Baden; he ascended the throne April 25, 1831, and died October 18, 1884.
The heir to Brunswick is the Duke of Cumberland, excluded owing to the refusal to give up the claim to the throne of Hanover.

The ducal house of Brunswick-Wolfenbuttel, extinct on the death of Wilhelm I, was long one of the most ancient and illustrious of the Germanic Confederation. Its ancestor, Henry the Lion, possessed, in the twelfth century, the united duchies of Bavaria and Saxony, with other territories in the North of Germany; but having refused to aid the Emperor Friedrich Barbarossa in his wars with the Pope, he was, by a decree of the Diet, deprived of the whole of his territories with the sole exception of his allodial domains, the principalities of Brunswick and Luneburg. These possessions were, on the death of Ernest the Confessor, divided between the two sons of the latter, who became the founders of the lines of Brunswick Luneburg, Elder Line, and Brunswick Luneburg, Younger Line,the former of which was represented in the ducal house of Brunswick, while the latter is merged in the royal family of Great Britain.

The Brunswick regency law of February 16, 1879, enacts that in case the legitimate heir to the Brunswick throne be absent or prevented from assuming the government, the Council of Regency, consisting of the Ministers of State and the Presidents of the Landtag and of the Supreme Court, should carry out the government, while the German Emperor should assume command of the military forces in the Duchy. If the rightful heir, after the space of a year, is unable to claim the throne, the Brunswick Landtag shall elect a regent from the non reigning members of German reigning families.
The Duke and Duchess of Cumberland left Copenhagen suddenly last week for Gmunden. Their departure is generally believed to be in connection with the Brunswick succession.
The Duke is said to be in the mood for compromise, but will only decide his attitude after a conference with his son.

div.head: DAMIETTA RAILWAY LINE.
div.p: The 5.20 a m. Tantah to Damietta train has been converted into a passenger train only and will leave at 7.15 a.m. in future, and arrive at Damietta at 11.15 a.m. instead of 12.50 p.m. The 6.5 p.m. Mansourah to Tantah train will start in future from Damietta leaving at 4 p m., and will arrive at Tantah at 7.30 p m. as now, connecting with the Cairo and Alexandria evening express trains. The mixed train, which at present leaves Damietta at 4.20 p m, will in future only start from Mansourah, leaving at 8.5 p.m., and arriving at Tantah at 11.0 p.m. as now.

div.head: CHILIAN TRAINING-SHIP AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Chilian training ship Generale Baquedano, under command of Captain Naf, and with a crew of 320, arrived in Alexandria harbor this morning from Biserta. She is a steel, sheathed, and coppered vessel of 2,500 tons' displacement with an average speed of 12 knots, a mean draught of 18ft., 240ft. in length, and has a beam of 45 ft. 9 in. Her armament consists of four 4.7in. quick firers two 12in., projected quick firers, two 6 in. projected quick firers, one field gun, two machine guns and one 18 in. torpedo tube. She is fitted with four Belleville boilers.

div.head: "AL LEWA" AND THE SYRIANS. KAMEL'S VITUPERATIONS
div.p: A very instructive example of the fanatical hatred of the organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamel to all Christians is seen in the "Al Lewa's" vituperation of the Syrians in consequence of the recent mutiny at Port Said. It was a very bad political stroke on the part of the Pasha's brother, who is the editor in the absence of the former, to manifest, so openly and at each a moment, that dislike of the so-called Nationalist Egyptian Press is not confined to the English and Europeans gone- rally, but equally embraces every race who does not profess the Creed of Islam. It is of course obvious that it is fanaticism which is at the bottom of the whole agitation, but this fact is carefully veiled by Mustapha Pasha Kamel, whose purpose it is to cloke the objects of the agitation by directing his attacks solely against the British Occupation. But the fact should never be lost sight of that the crusade is really directed against all Christians, just as was the former nationalist outburst Lord Milner in "England in Egypt" notes the fact

"As a matter of fact, the Arabist movement passed with frightful rapidity from a protest against the abuse of European influece to an attack upon that influence in every form; and it was passing at the moment when it was arrested into an attack not only open everything European, but upon everything Christian. The ever smouldering hatred of Moslem for Copt had been stirred into flame, and in another month the half-million and upwards of native Christians of Egypt, including many of its richest and most intelligent inhabitants, would have gone the way of their hated rivals, the Syrians, and have swelled the list of the proscribed."

The fanaticism of the Nationalists is as comprehensive in its all-embracing character at the present moment as it was in the days of Arabic Pasha. But it was a fatal "faux pas" on the part of "Al Lewa" to make this fact patent to all the world just at the present moment, for it has given all the Syrians and Copts of Egypt an insight into the realities of the present agitation, which would not: have been brought home to them by the most virulent Anglophobe speeches of Mustapha Pasha Kamel. The mattar has been taken up by the vernacular Press and the Coptic daily papers. "Al Watan," remarks:

"We have certainly never seen calumnies so vile, insults so shameful, denoting the extremity of baseness, and the total lack of education, as those which the journal "Al Lewa" has drivelled out a propos of the Assyr incident in accusing the Syrian soldiers of coward ice and low birth. This paper apparently thought that the soldiers who mutinied were Christians, and its shameless fanaticism found therein another occasion to indulge in tirades. If, however, it bad the least good sense or the intelligence, it would have known for all that, that the Syrian soldiers are the real prop of Turkey, and that Syria is the pearl of the Ottoman possessions. It might also have known that it is the Syrians whom it impudently qualifies as of base origin who really have all the power in Turkey, and that it is the politics of these same Syrians which it glorifies with such enthusiasm ; if it were not wholly blinded by its fanaticism it might have known that neither the Sultan nor his Government have yet written the name Syrian without its infallible corollary : honour. And is not the insult of this vile sheet a railing against humanity and opprobrium against itself. And this insult is directed against no other than a country which has already sacrificed 300,000 of its children in the service of Turkey; and it is against all these brave men who are cut down in the Yemen, after nameless struggles and the most terrible sufferings, that the organ of the gutter press has just cast it hideous affront ! We know of nothing more craven, more vile, or ignoble than the shameful soul which drivels execration and ignominy.

A Moslem Ulema of Al Azhar University writes to 'Al-Ahram" a long article in which he quotes several ayets of the Koran and some Hadiths of the Prophet to show that Syria, which has been maligned by "Al-Lewa" in the course of its comments on the Assyr mutiny, is the most sacred country in the world. The following is one of the prophet's Hadiths mentioned in the article:

"The good being divided into ten tenths, Syria holds nine tenths of it, while all the other countries hold only one tenth ; and the evil being nine tenths, only one tenth of it exists in Syria while eight tenths are spread throughout the other countries ; if the inhabitants of Syria become corrupt there will be no good in ye."

The writer concludes as follows : "I have only written this article to show the people the results of the publications of "Al-Lewa" in the service of Moslems and Islam, and how it mistreats the faith and its principles in writing according to its own ends. "Al-Lewa" separates the Mohamedans from each other, and calls upon them to despise one another while we are in full need of winning the sympathy of all the other nations.

div.head: A MAHMOUDIEH TRAGEDY.
div.p: BRUTAL MURDER OF A GIRL.

Yesterday another of the many tragedies of Alexandria, that have been revealed from the miry waters of the Mahmoudieh Canal, was disoovered. A strange looking canvas sack was seen in the canal near Ramleh and some fellaheen, whose curiosity was aroused, fished it out of the water. They found it very heavy and when they had succeeded in getting it ashore, they were horrified at finding that it contained the mangled remnants of a young woman. She was a young native woman, eighteen years of age, and evidently was of an extremely pre- possessing type of Egyptian beauty. When they had emptied the sack of its contents, they found that the neck had been almost severed by a terrific gash, while the abdomen was covered with gaping wounds, in fact everything tended to show that they had discovered the victim of a most determined and cold-blooded murder. One of the men ran for a policeman, and the body was taken to the Government hospital, where a post-mortem examination was held yesterday afternoon. It was found that the young woman had been about to become a mother, and it is concluded that it is "crime passionnel." No traces of the murderer have as yet been discovered and there are no clues on the girl's clothing or body which can in any way be of assistance in disclosing her identity.

div.head: AMERICAN DIPLOMATIC REPRESENTATION.
div.p: The Hos. Lewis Morris Iddings, the American Diplomatic Agent and Consul General in Egypt, is not expected to return to Egypt util November. During Mr. Idding's summer leave the acting American Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General has been an American Missionary at Cairo, the Rev. Mr. Giffin.

div.head: THE HELLENIC AGENCY.
div.p: M. Pappadiamantopoulo, who has been appointed Hillenic Diplomatic Agent and Consul General in Egypt, in succession to M. Gennadis, has been secretary to Prince George in Crete,and was up to lately Hellenic Minister at Cettigne. M. Psycha, first secretary to the agency, has arrived in Cairo and assumed charge. M. Callerghis, who has been for some time Charge d'Affaires at Cairo, will not return but will resume his former duties at Stamboul.

div.head: NILE EXPRESS CO.
div.p: The Nile Express Steamer Co. have two new boats of the stern wheel type designed by Mr. Shilston for this season's tourist traffic. These boats are splendidly furnished with electric fans, telephones and other up-to-date appliances. This new company is receiving strong support more especially from America. Mr. Frank Clarke, the great American tourist agent, has entered into a contract with the company. The two new boats will be named the America and Virginia and will begin running early in January. The Nile Express Steamer Co. have taken over the barges and business of one of the Nile Transports companies and are now carrying merchandise between Alexandria and Cairo.

div.head: CURIOUS DISCOVERY AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: The second report of the Wellcome Research Laboratories, Gordon Memorial College, Khartoum, describes an interesting discovery of a noval use for asbestos. On opening an ancient grave at Naga in the Egyptian Sudan, the bones of a human being were found, at a depth of 4ft., surrounded with a feather-like substance, which proved to be asbestos.

The indications go to prove that this skeleton is more than 1,500 years old, since the brickwork of the grave appears to have come from some building belonging to the town of Naga, which was still flourishing between 300 a.d. and 400 a.d. Whether the burial occurred during the Christian period, or during the Muslim period subsequent to 1500 a.d., the discoverers are unable to say.

div.head: FLOUR MILL ON FIRE.
div.p: A fire broke out yesterday about noon in flour mill situated at Kafr el Ashri, Alexandria. Although the premises were occupied at the time the alarm was not given to the fire brigade by those in charge, and it was due to the action of a passer by—that the services of the brigade were called in, not before, however, the conflagration had got a good hold of the building. After an hours hard work the outbreak was subdued, and the damage done is estimated at over L.E. 120.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: MRS. ALDBRSON.

We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Alderson, the wife of our esteemed fellow citizen, Mr. George B Alderson, which occurred yesterday in England. Mrs. Alderson had a wide circle of friends in Egypt and the greatest sympathy will be felt for her husband and family in their bereavement. Mrs. Alderson was a devoted wife and mother and had borne with exemplary patience and resignation the burthen of a terrible malady for some years past. We beg to tender our sincere sympathies to the widower and family.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit- within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: POSTAL ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—Your correspondent who writes under the above heading has exposed a legitimate ground of complaint —a complaint be it observed which touches Europeans and natives alike who have business and other connections with the United Kingdom.

When last year that redoubtable champion of postal reform, Mr. Henniker Heaton, induced the British and Egyptian Governments to lower the letter postage rate it is hard to conceive that he was cognizant of the inequality which such a boon was about to inaugurate, viz : that whilst the charge for letters from the United Kingdom to Egypt was henceforth to be reduced by one penny half penny the half ounce, that for letters from Egypt to the United Kingdom was to be reduced by one penny farthing only.

I should like to know why there should be a discrimination against this country of 20% ? It would also be interesting to discover whether this 20 % is retained by the Egyptian Treasury or in what proportion it is shared by other countries which have, by arrangement with Egypt, adopted the reduced rate.

As postal officials, like those of other Egyptian administrations, are prohibited, on pain of dismissal, from writing to the Press, and we are not likely to get any enlightenment from that quarter it would, therefore, be a good thing and possibly lead to the removal of such injustice if the Hon. Member for Canterbury could be persuaded to ask from his place in the British House of Commons for this much desired piece of information.—I am, etc,
Cairo, September 26, 1906. Inquirer.

div.head: THE SALT MONOPOLY.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette.' Sir,—I noticed in yesterday's issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" a letter from a Cairo correspondent complaining of the quality of the salt sold in this country. Your correspondent is probably unaware that, not only in both Alexandria and Cairo, but in all the chief towns and villages of Egypt, the Egyptian Markets Limited have undertaken the sale of the salt of the Port Said Silt Association Limited, which supplies common and ground salt and also table salt from England. As a a sample of the excellence of this salt I herewith submit to your notice the text of the analytical report made at the chemical laboratory of the Norwegian Government at Bergen of the Port Said salt and the Trapani (common) salt:-

Port Said Salt. Taipani Salt Sodium chloride (pure sail) 97.40% 86.10% Magnesium chloride 0 16 1.46 Calcium sulphate 0.83 0.57 Natrium sulphate 0.02 1.49 Impurities and insoluble matter 0.04 0.24 Humidity 0.90 9.95 99.35 99.81 N.B. When the sum of these figures does not reach the 100 % it is due to unavoidable errors in the analyses.

" A mere glance at these figures shows at " once the great difference in the real values " of these two samples of salt. This difference " is specially marked in the respective proportions " of humidity and pure salt. " The Port Said Salt has a low humidity " which renders it low to handle and a low " content of magnesium chloride which " would always tend to keep it comparatively " dry. The Salt is very strong, the " content of pure salt being very high " (another sample of salt which I am now " examining contains only 88 % pure salt). " The best butter salt can only hold up to " 99:50% pure salt. "
Signed. Harald Gregg.
Dated: Bergen, 7th August, 1906.
Your correspondent has only to make the the experiment and test for himself. I remain. Trudy Yours, "C.S."
Alexandria, 26th September.

div.head: THE GREAT PYRAMID.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." Sir—When the Great Pyramid is made accessible to visitors, as it soon must be, by eleotric lighting, handrails, &c, it only remains for the Department of Antiquities to cleanse the surfaces of the masonry in the passages, blackened by so many hundred years of smoky encrustations. This can easily be effected by the invention known as the "steambrush," need to freshen the aspect of London buildings. It is merely a nuzzle held in the hand, connected by a flexible tube with a small boiler generating steam at a moderate pressure, and directed on the wall from a ladder or scaffold. The jet, without injuring the stone in the slightest degree, would very quickly restore its colours to those of the original granites and limestones. Yours etc. Cairo, September 27. A.T.F.

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: To the Editor or the "Egyptian Gazette." Sir,—I absolutely protest most strongly against the insinuations of your Cairo correspondent who calls himself "Another resident of over 20 years' standing" and his endeavour to throw dirt on the commercial community.
His attempt to cast blame on an honourable and well behaved lot of citizens is, it appears, on a par with the want of tact and courtesy with which be has lately been accused in your columns.

I know, and am in possession of documentary proof, that some people here endeavour to make it appear a disgrace and belittling to wear or have worn the King's uniform, but although knowing this I did not imagine that they would attack the whole commercial community in the way he has done-in the hope of covering their own sins.—Faithfuly Yours. P. Plunkett.
"Au De Rouge."
Cairo, September 23.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Ministers will take up their official residence at Cairo on October 10.
Hussein Pasha Moharren will, it is reported, be appointed Eruir el Hag for the coming pilgrimage.
Khalil Pasha Hemads, Director of the Alexandria douane, left yesterday for Cairo.
Court Bernsdorff, the new German Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, is expected to arrive in Cairo on the 10th November.

Mr. A.P. Mack, the Managing Director of the Nile Valley (New) Company Limited, and Director of the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, arrived in Cairo yesterday by the mail route. He will shortly be making a visit to Um Garaiart, where, we understand, the mine is developing well.
The celebrated French composer, Mr. Saint- Saens, intends to pay a visit to Egypt this season, and is arriving in Cairo in January.
Cherif Pasha, the Ottoman Minister at Stockholm, has arrived at Cairo, where he intends passing part of the winter.
Captain Francisco E. Nef, commandant at the Chilian training ship Generate Banquedano, now in harbour, paid a visit to the Governor this morning.

div.head: ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
div.p: By kind permission of Major C.J.L. Davidson, D.S.0. commanding, and Officers, of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme of music in the Esbekieh Gardens to-morrow evening from 9 to 11 p.m.

Military March—Pomp and Circumstance—Elgar Ouverturo—Fra Diavolo—Auber Cornet Solo—Tho Holy City—Stephen Adams (Soloist Mus. Lewis) Reminiscences of Meyerbeer—err. A. F. Godfrey- Airs from Operas—L'Africaine—L'Etoile du Nord— Les Huguenots—Dinorah—Le Prophete—Robert le Diable. Valse—Toujours au Jamais—Waldteufel Polacca—Picaroon —Green (Soloist Cpl O'Neal) Grand Selection from Wagner's—Opera Tannhauser arr.G. Godfrey. Patrol—The Crack Regiment—Tobani. Regimental March—The Khedivial Anthem God Save the King. R. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster

"Inhabitant" writes from Cairo :—A popular musical programme attracted a large number of people to the the Esbekieh Gardens on Tuesday evening last, when the band of the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers performed. The works performed included Elgar's Salut D'Amour, and "Die Zigeuherin" from the Bohemian Girl. One of the most appreciated items consisted of selections from Boito's Mefistofele, and the Belle of New York was also greatly appreciated. A large number warmly applauded the descriptive fantasia "March Across the Desert,"and the humorous piece "a Darktown Donkey Race" fairly enraptured them. It will be seen that it was one of the beat arranged programmes we have had in the Esbekieh Gardens for some time, as the chief aim of it was to please everybody. In conclusion I should like to say a few words about this band which I have had the pleasure of hearing on many occasions.

On making careful enquiry I have found out that this band has always been kept up the high standard of efficiency. In 1895 it took first first at a contest held by the Arts and Crafts Society of Ireland. Since then they have bad the honour of playing on many notable occasions. Daring the visit of the Emperor of Germany to Gibraltar this band was specially complimented by his Majesty, and as I understand that this battalion is shortly to leave this station In write this letter in appreciation of the splendid programmes provided by their band during their short stay in Cairo.

div.head: EGYPT 100 YEARS AGO.
div.p: From the "Times" of Friday. September 13, 1806:— The following is the language in which this braggart (General Regnier), whose presumption has met with so severe a rebuke from General Stuart on the plains of Malda, has dared to speak of that glorious band of Britons which achieved the conquest of Egypt. In speaking of the action which took place on on the 13th of March, five days after the British Army landed in Egypt, he says— "The French Army consisted only of 8,830 infantry, 520 cavalry, and 31 pieces of cannon; while the English had 16,000 infantry, 2,000 marines from the fleet, 200 cavalry, and 10 pieces of cannon. And yet, notwithstanding this immense superiority of number, the English did not dare to begin the attack." His account of the battle of the 13th of March, which decided the fate of Egypt, is equally candid and correct.—He concludes his account of the campaign in the following words: —"The expedition of the English has succeeded, but they have gathered only the laurels of success; for never did they ensure victory by their military movements, their courage, or their enterprize. Their timid march, not withstanding their enormous superiority, perfectly points out what would have-been their fate, if the Chief of the French Army (Menou) had been worthy of his troops."

div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, le 26 Septembre

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a é'é réduit hier de 1 8 é 4 3/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a gagné 1 S á 86 1/8. L'Unifiée est restés invariée á 104 1/2, de même que la National Bank á 26 5/8. L'Agricole a perdu 1/8 á 9 3/4. La Daira a avancé de 1/8 á 16 7/8. La Delta Light est demeurée inchangée á 11/12.
A Parie, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a progressé de 1 franc á 779. La Banque d'Athènes est restée stationnaire á 144.

Rassuré par une première rédaction du taux de l'escompte libre á Londres, ainsi que par des achats du découvert, sur certains titrer, notre marché des valeurs a été, ce matin, pins soutenu qu'hier. Il serait assurément, prématuré de prévoir une reprise sérieuse immédiate, mais il est incontestable que les appréhensions exagérées de ces derniers jours tendent á sattéuuer et á faire place á des despositions meilleures.

La National Bank a débuté á 26 7/16 pour clôturer á 24 1/2-9 16 L'Agricole est restée á 9 11/18. Le Comptoir Financier a molli á 6 7/16 1/2 l'action ancienne et 6 1/4-5/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Abyssinie s'est rallermie á 6 1/2-9/16.

Le Crédit Foncier a avancé á 777-778. La Nile Land a gagné 3/16 á 14 5/8. L'Immobilière a fléchi á 385. L'action Agricole du Nil a réactionné á 270 L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été échangée á 4 18-3/16 et la part de fondateur á 68. L'Union Foncière est remontée á 6-6 1/16. La part de fondateur Allotment a été mieux tenue á 125-126.
La Delta Light a été offerte á 11 5/8 sans acheteurs. Les Joussances Eaux du Caire se sont alourdies á 265-266. Les parts de fondes teur Automobiles du Caire ont fléchi á 10 7/16.

Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont progressé á 17 1/4 l'action ancienne et 17 1/8 la nouvelle. En bonne demande, les Egyptien ont avancé á 6 3/16-1/4. ' Les Upper Egypt ont été également recherchés á 4 3/4 Les National ont bénéficié de plus de 3/8 á 4; leur part de fondateur a été cotée 56
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont clôturé à 3 5/16, acheteurs Les Hooker ont reculé á 0 15/16. Les Cotton Mils ont fait 6 sh.

Le solde de la propriété Gianaclis á Kasr-el Aiui, y compris le palais, a été acheté par l'Egyptian Improvements Corporation en participation avec an groupe, au prix de 12 livres le mètre, avec des conditions de paiement trè avantageuses.
Un lot du plan de lotissement, qui a été éta bli, vient d'être vendu á 27 livres le mètre, et ce même prix aurait été refusé pour une antre parcelle.
On ajoute que U Société est eu train de traiter plusieurs Toutes appelées k donner on gros bénéfice.
On affirme de bonne source que M.E. Toriel aurait résolu de donner sa démission d'administrateur de l'Egyptian Land and General Trust Ltd. (Hooker).
D'autre part, le brait court que le Conseil d'administration aurait décidé de faire l'appel du 3ème quart de 5 sh. dans les première jours da moie prochain.

Nous détachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date do 18 Septembre, le passage suivant : ' L'notion Banque Impériale Ottomane a sensiblement progressé Bl'e a atteint et fran ehi le cours de 679 pour revenir en fin de semaine à 669. 11 y a tonte probabilité pour que le dividende de l'exercice en cours soit maintenu á 20 francs, sinon augmenté csr la conversion des Priorités ottomanes et l'émis sion des obligations Damas Hamah privilégiées ont dû procurer de larges bénéfices. Il faut s attendre aussi, d'un moment á l'autre, á la conversion par les soins de la Banque des Ottomanes 4 % 1896.

Les recettes toutes depuis le 1er Janvier 1906 ont atteint la somme de L.E. 59,557 contre 50,488 en 1905, soit avec une plus value de L.E. 9,119 pour l'exercice courant.
Les recettes de l'Alexandrie Ramleh Railway Co. au 22 Septembre courant ont atteint L.E. 1,347 contre 1,132 en 1905, soit en augmentation de L.E. 215.
Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Octobre 1905, se sont élevés á L.E. 61,735 contre 49,707 en 1905, soit en plus value de L.E. 12,028.

div.p: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Cazette."

The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed,and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head:
CRETAN INSURGENTS.
FRANCE'S DEPARTURE HINDERED.
BRITISH SOLDIERS LAND.

div.p: Insurgents were assembled at Halepa in expectation that Prince George would embark there They broke through the cordon of the international troops and firing ensued. Some were wounded on both sides. The British cruiser Barham has landed bluejackets and machine guns. (Reuter)

During the affray of Halepa Prince George, move departure insurgents wished to revent, was guarded by international troops at his residence. He afterwards sailed for Athens on board a Greek battleship unnoticed. (R.)
The Cretans attempted to prevent the departure of Prince George. The troops of the Powers fired, and the Cretans replied. Two Cretans and a Russian kawas were killed. (H.)
Prince George has arrived, and was much acclaimed. (Havas)

Owing to the unfavourable reports made by Mr. Taft regarding the Cuban Government's attitude, which is rejecting the terms of peace, more warships and marines have been ordered to proceed to Cuba. Altogether 7,000 men are prepared to land. (Reuter)

The President and Vice President will tender their resignation to Congress to-morrow. All the ministers and heads of departments have already resigned. It is stated that Cuba will be governed by a commission appointed by the United States. (Reuter)
President Roosevelt has ordered all the available marines to proceed to Cuba. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE RUSSIAN MASSACRES
INCITED BY GOVERNOR GENERAL.

div.p: Governor General Kaulbars has alarmed the city by a remarkable speech encouraging the massacre makers. In reply to a deputation complaining that the "Union of the Russian People" was massacring peacefnl citizens, Jews and Christians alike, the General said that the members of the Union were the Tsar's best sons whom the Government esteemed and that the citizens were thus punished for toleratiog revolutionaries in their midst (R.)
The revolted peasantry of the province of Katka are masters of the strategic positions. (Havas)
The International Conference for the protection of workmen has been closed. (Havas)
Heavy floods are reported from the provinces of Mercia and Alicante. (Havas)
The Marquis of Pallavicini, the Austro Hungarian Ambassador at Bukharest, has been appointed Ambassador here. (Reuter)

div.head: The Condition of tho Indian Ryots.
div.p: We cannot agree with Professor Beesley that the alleged impoverishment of India is a question which could be adequately investigated by a Royal Commission, unless their deliberations were preceded by years of patient historical research. But, if only because of the nefarious uses to which popular ignorance is turned by fanatical or unscrupulous agitators. We hold that the question deserves far more careful study than has yet been bestowed upon it. The results of each study, we are convinced, would show conclusively that British rule, far from having led to the impoverishment of India, has arrested or largely reduced every one of the evils which were still draining her wealth even a hundred years ago. For it has given India what India never knew before—safety against the incursions of predatory hordes from Central Asia, freedom from internal strife and turmoil, upright Judges, and an upright Administration, and, as a con- sequence of all this, security for life and property for every caste and race and creed, such as can nowhere be traced in the records of her chequered history before we gave peace to her countless millions. ("Times.")

div.head: The Seditions In Bengal.
div.p: It is the duty of the executive government to see that every section enjoys the liberty and protection to which all subjects of the British Crown are entitled. Hindus must not be allowed to provoke Mahomedans either by insult or threats of violence; most be given no excuse for taking the law into their own bands. The criminal procedure cede is not silent on the subject of seditious writing in the Press or seditious speeches on the platform; and its provisions must be enforced. What, perhaps, is most important of ail, people in England must understand that imputations made against the authorities in India, by a little group of retired Anglo Indian officials who have come home with grievances of their own to ventilate, carry with them their own refutation. Quite enough harm has been done already by letting it be supposed in India that those gentlemen ware educating the public at home to believe in the honesty and loyalty cf the National Congress. ("Standard.")

div.head: Party Courtesies.
div.p: The autumn session has killed the usual autumn campaign. Liberal statesmen are busied with fruitful administrative work, and ex Ministers have apparently nothing better to do than to quarrel over Mr. Balfour's past and to clamour for the MacDonnell letters. Oar mood is singularly friendly, and while Mr. Wyndham makes graceful speeches holding up Mr. Gladstone as an example to youth, the rest of us are looking forward with a kindly welcome to Mr. Chamberlain's reappearance on a platform. ("Tribune.")

div.head: Temptations of the Peerage.
div.p: In order to live and die unmarried in the present day a nobleman must possess at once a heart of adamant and a sublime contempt for pounds, shillings, and pence. In his youth he must withstand all the sirens of the music hall and the Gaiely stage. If he escapes them in safety, it is only to encounter in his more mature years the wily assiduity of the professional dealers, who move insidiously in polite society, and catch their prey unawares at the dinner table, in the drawing-room, at fashionable restaurants, or yachting in the Solent. ("Truth")

div.head: Germany and South Africa
div.p: We can only be grateful to the Secretary of State for War for pointing out that the apprehensions cf nervous people regarding the concentration of German troops in South Africa are baseless, for it is to be hoped that the utterance of this respected and reasonable man will make a deeper impression on those nervous minds than the most explicit declaration of the German Press. If we have hitherto refrained from setting forth very good reasons which would dispel the anxiety felt by Englishmen of an excessively distrustful disposition, it is because we did not think that they affected any but the very narrowest and unimportant circle. ("Cologne Gazette").

div.head: Sir F. Lugard's Resignation
div.p: The fact of Sir P. Lugard's resignation must inevitably direct attention to the various suggestions which from time to time have been put forward with a view to securing greater continuity, and, therefore, greater efficiency in the administration of our tropical possessions. Attention is being directed to the importance of securing 'continuity' not merely in our Colonial policy as a whole, but in meeting the needs of individual Crown Colonies and Protectorates, which in their physical conditions and existing institutions demand infinite flexibility and diversity of handling." ("Morning Post")

div.head: Russia.
div.p: Yesterday we were told that skeins of wild geese were winging their way southwards, from which it is surmised that the long Arctic winter has set in early. This morning we have rumours of a mysterious passage through Berlin and across Germany of a Royal train filled with Russian Grand Dukes and their families, which if true suggests that their autocratic northern homes are no longer habitable. Whether it be true or not, the chaos in Russia seems to get more hopeless day by day. There is a letter in the papers today signed by Mr. David L Alexander, Mr Glands G Montefiore, and Mr. Leopold da Rothschild, as representatives of the Jewish Board of Deputies, and the Anglo Jewish Board of Deputies, and the Anglo Jewish Association, drawing attention to a telegram which has just been received from Russia, to the effect that during the recent pogrom in Siedlce more than two hundred persons were arrested haphazard and are being brought before a court martial, on which are sitting as judges the very same officers who took an active part in the terrible events which recently occurred in that Polish town. The letter appeals earnestly that the voice of the country may be raised to prevent the threatened further slaughter of Jews in the Russian provinces. ("Westminster Gazette.")

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The Bank of England is read, in a stronger position than it was last week, for although the reserve has fallen very slightly, it is higher than at this time last year, and the larger portion of the Autumn demand has been satisfied. It is thought probable that the gold coming forward from the various gold-fields, amounting to four millions per month, will supply most of the farther requirements, with some help from the Bank of France. The bold and novel step taken by the old lady of Threadneedle Street of raising the price of gold bars to 78e./ld. (well above the outside market, 77s /11 1/2 d.) will have the effect of diverting the demand from her, and it is much more sensible than increasing the Bank rate, which unnecessarily disturbs other markets. Altogether, a cheerful view is taken of the money prospects. The discount he uses are allowing 3% for call money, and 3 1/4 for "notice" money, and are charging 3 3/4 to 4% for short paper, and 4 1/4% for three months' bills.
Silver.
Silver has sagged a little during the week, but it is again firmer, with quotations same as last week, 31 9/16 spot and 31 7/8 two months forward.
The Stock Markets.

In our last article we expressed the hope that the increased Bank rate would be effective in improving the monetary outlook, and thus affording to the stock markets the support they so much need. Unfortunately the past week has been even more hopeless, so far as investment business is concerned, than for some time past. Further large withdrawals of gold from the Bank for America, Constantinople, and Egypt have kept the better-class stocks in a nervous state, and it is feared that another increase in the Bank rate will be necessary before a normal state of affairs ran be realised. A very disturbing feature also has been the rise in the Berlin Bank rate to 5%, which had an immediately depressing effect upon the gilt-edged and home railway markets. In consequence of these adverse influences, the amount of business transacted on the Stock Exchange has been extremely slight, and prices all round show substantial declines. Yesterday and to-day being Jewish holidays, the House has had a deserted appearance, and the tone of markets is quiet in the extreme.
Consols.

The gilt-edged market commenced with a show of firmness, but the further heavy drains on the Bank, and the increase in the rate of the Bank at Berlin proved too much for its equanimity, and all the stocks have fallen away, Consols now being no better than 85 5/16.
Foreign Bonds.

A satisfactory feature of the foreign market at the beginning of the week was the strength of Russians, the Fours at one time improving to 72 1/2. Subsequently they were influenced by the depression in other sections, and relapsed, but they firmed up again yesterday, and close steady tonight at 72, the script of the new loan at 11 discount Japanese are fractionally weaker.
Home Rails.

This section has had seveveral causes for depression—though doubtless some dealers will say that home rails can usually, in these days, succeed in being miserable without cause. First of all, dear money was a bear influence, then there was a strike in one of the departments of the Midland railway, and to complete the tale of misfortunes came the terrible disaster on the Great Northern line at Grantham. The result has been a week of idleness, with lower quotations in nearly all the shares. On the announcement of the Scotch Express smash York Deferred dropped 2 points, dosing 1 1/2 down on the day. In several other cases losses of a full point were marked.
Americans.

The tone of American railway shares has been uncertain, and in the main quotations are below last Friday's levels. Readings are the only point that have shown any buoyancy, there being about 4 7/8 higher at 78 7/8. Baltimore and Ohio have gained 3 1/4 at 129, and Unions have lost 1/2 at 194 3/4 on our last.
The market opened with a better tendency to day, Southern Pacifics being a good feature with a rise cf nearly three dollars. These leave off to-night at 97 7/8.
Egyptians.

There is hardly any business doing in the Egyptian section, and as the markets in Egypt are closed until Monday there is not likely to be much revival until next week. National Banks are better at 26 13/16, but Agricultural Banks are unchanged at 9 13/16. The Debentures of the latter are 96 3/4 3 1/4 Corporation of Western Egypt have been in request, and are strong buyers at 3/8 premium. Daira close about the same at 16 7/8, and the Deferred at 100. Daira Sugar are unchanged at 2 5/8, Delta Land and Investment, after being 3 5/15, close better again at 3 1/2, but Delta Preference Bearer are unmentioned, being nominally 11 1/4 3/4, while the Deferred are supposed to be 10-13. Egyptian Estates close 1 7/8, and Egyptian Markets 1 1/4. Salt and Soda have been offered at 1 1/8 without response. Khedivial Mail Ordinary have changed hands as high as 36s. 3d. Abyssinian Banks are quoted 1 1/4 3/4 discount, and Union Fonciere are unchanged at 5 3/4 6. Land Bank of Egypt are a fraction harder at 9 middle, and Bank of Roumania remain unchanged at 10 1/4.
Mining.

The uncertainty regarding the prospects of money continue to restrict business in the South African market, while during the past two days the absence of the Jewish members has caused the Kaffir section to be particularly helpless.
Rhodesians, after being very dull, closed rather firmer yesterday, Tanganyikas gaining 1/16 at 6 7/16. They are now 6 5/8, a rise of 1/8 to-day. Chartered were also 1/16 better at 1 9/32.
Rand mines leave off weak to-night at 6 3/16 and East Rands at 4 1/6.
Egyptian mining shares remain almost idle. Nile Valleys yesterday recovered to 6/, and Egyptian Mines exploration to 4/-s.
The closing prices to-night are as follow:-

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
Liverpool, September 20.
The Market for Egyptians has been quiet again this week, the only change in quotations being a redaction of 1/8 per lb for fine.
A moderate business has been done in Futures; the following are the latest values:
Sept. 9.17 Dec. 8.13 March 8.4 Oot 8.51 Jan. 8.7 April 8.4 Nov. 8.27 Febr. 8.4 May 8.4

American Futures -The market this week has been fairly active, and prices have experienced constant fluctuations. On Tuesday there was an advance of 10 points, but it has not been maintained,and today's closing values are practically unchanged from those of last Thursday. The general sentiment remains bearish, although lets pronouned than of late. The accounts of the crop are generally considered favorable, the movement remains smaller than last year owing to the crop being about a couple of weeks late, and larger receipts are predicted shortly. There is at the moment very little speculative interest everyone wishing to see farther developments in one direction or the other. The latest quotations are, delivery:—

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
div.p: SECTION COTONNIERE
Questionnaire de Septembre 1906
Priére de réspondre avant le 5 Octobre en vous servant de la langue que vous préférex
1.—Dites-nous si la température en Septembre a été favorable
2. — Dites nous l'on a constaté des vers et des brouillards en Septembre?
3. —Ces différentes causes ont-elles fait des dégâts aux Cotonniers, et à combien les estimez vous?
4.- La cueillette a-t-elle commencé, et jusqu'à quel point est-elle en avance ou en retard, chez vous en comparaison de l'ancée passée?
5. —Croyez vous que la première cueillette sera supérieure à celle de l'an dernier et de combien?
6.—Que penne vous des perrprotives, de la cueillette de coton dite "Nili"?
7.—La récolte, chez vous, séra-t-elle supérieure ou inférieure à la précédente et de combien?
8. - Le rendement a l'égrenage est il égal, supérieur ou inférieur à celui de l'année dernière et de combien pour cent, pour: le Mit-Afifi? l'Abassi? le Joanovich? l'Ashmouni?
9.- Quel est l'aspect des cultures en général?
Pour le Comité
Le Président en fonction
H. Lindemann.

Yesterday the wind was light from the N.N.E., and some of the prettiest sailing was witnessed that has ever been seen at the Yacht Club. The start of the second class was particularly so, as the four boats leaving at 3.45 all got under way with their spinnakers set. Owing to the proximity of the boats or Class I. finishing as Class II were completing the first round a great many fools occurred and a great many decisions rested with the officer of the day and the sailing committee. Some of these have not yet been completed but this will not effect the Coot winning the monthly prize in Class I. and the Iskindiriyah winning Chitty Bey's cup in Class II, against which boats no fouls are claimed.
Owing to an error the Isis II. was started at her wrong time and her finishing time not taken.

The Company has 90 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 31-12.905
